I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.   In response to the request from the Government of Cambodia, the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) included a technical assistance (TA) project in its country operations business plan, 
2017–2019.1 The  TA  will  strengthen  government  capacity  for  improved  implementation  of 
externally funded projects and improve the effectiveness and results of development interventions 
in Cambodia2. Improved management of development projects will support the government’s 
ongoing reform efforts in public financial management and enhance good governance in the 
public sector. During the TA fact-finding mission, conducted in February 2017, the government 
concurred  with  the  impact,  outcomes,  implementing  arrangements,  costs  and  financing 
arrangements, and terms of reference for consultants. The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.    The demand for public investments in Cambodia has increased in line with Cambodia’s 
rapid economic growth, which averaged 7% per year from 2000 to 2015. External financing 
through official development assistance has played a large role in filling this gap, providing about 
two-thirds of the government’s annual development budget.4 With the expansion of development 
assistance, government is under pressure to deliver quality results quickly. This, in turn, requires 
a  sound  and  sustainable  operational  system  that  reinforces  good  governance  in  project 
management.  Since  2004,  development  partners  provided  assistance  and  support  to  the 
government to address financial and human capacity constraints to achieving its development 
objectives.  However,  these  efforts  have  mostly  been  fragmented  and  project-based  and, 
therefore, their impacts on the overall implementation of externally funded projects have been 
limited.5   
 
3.  Despite risk mitigation measures built in externally funded projects, project implementation 
risk remains high due to weak operational and management capacity, which is reflected in the 
overall portfolio performance (e.g., disbursement ratios, project start-up compliance, and loan 
extensions). Implementation is constrained by poor construction industry standards and a limited 
number of qualified service providers (e.g., consultants, contractors, and suppliers in the market). 
Underlying  these  constraints  are  systemic  issues  such  as  the  limited  ownership  and 
unsatisfactory  supervision  of  projects,  limited  capacity  of  the  executing  and  implementing 
agencies, and lengthy procedures in the approval of project documents.    
 
4.  With  assistance  from  the  World  Bank,  ADB,  and  other  development  partners,  the 
government adopted the standard operating procedures (SOPs) for externally funded projects to 
align  project  management,  procurement,  and  financial  management  with  international 
practices—a milestone achieved in 2012.6 While the framework for project implementation has 
been established, the quality of investments throughout the project cycle needs improvement.

5.  The TA will build on past efforts to improve project implementation and build the capacity 
of the executing and implementing agencies in the areas of project management, procurement, 
financial management, governance, and gender mainstreaming. In addressing the issue of the 
capacity of the executing and implementing agencies and other systemic issues, the TA will carry 
out  an  assessment  of  binding  constraints  to  effective  implementation  to  identify  long-term 
solutions. This will require (i) improved mechanisms to ensure project preparation, readiness, and 
implementation through effective project readiness filters and advance actions; (ii) strengthened 
and sustainable implementation capacity of the executing and implementing agencies, including 
the  possibility  of  partnering  with  national training  institutions for  long-term  and  sustainable 
capacity building; and (iii) strategic, coordinated, and effective knowledge management, which 
includes, but is not limited to, diagnostic studies that address systemic issues underpinning 
portfolio performance as well as thematic issues that affect project quality (e.g., governance and 
gender mainstreaming). The knowledge base derived from these activities will be used as a basis 
for further policy dialogue with the government.  
  
III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
6.  The government’s National Strategic Development Plan, 2014–2018 focuses on the 
promotion  of  agriculture,  physical  infrastructure,  private  sector  development,  and  human 
resources underpinned by a results-based monitoring and evaluation framework.7 In ensuring 
effective and sustained public investments, the government since 2015 has been developing its 
public investment management strategy, which will be supported by three subdecrees–one of 
which will cover guidelines and procedures for externally funded projects.8  
 
7.  The country partnership and strategy, 2014–2018 for Cambodia emphasizes two strategic 
pillars: strengthening of rural–urban–regional linkages and human resource development, and 
strengthening public sector management.9 To achieve these, it is imperative that investments are 
results-based and that projects deliver their intended outcomes. The TA supports ADB’s Strategy 
2020 Midterm Review Action Plan in terms of improving operational efficiencies, preparing 
projects better, improving project readiness, and facilitating organizational change to meet new 
challenges,  particularly  in  light  of  greater  empowerment  to  resident  missions  in  portfolio 
management and project implementation.10  
 
8.  Previous TA projects on enhancing project implementation and strengthening country 
systems have led to some capacity improvements of the executing and implementing agencies in 
the  areas  of  project  administration,  procurement,  and  financial  management,  following  the 
government’s promulgation of the SOPs. The TA projects provided support in operationalizing the 
subdecree, conducted training programs, and produced a cadre of trainers in procurement and 
financial management. However, the outreach of these capacity building programs has been 
rather limited and the effectiveness of these programs has been uneven; as well, the utilization of 
good  implementation  practices  has  been  limited  and  will  need  greater  attention.  The  TA, 
therefore, builds on results from the previous related interventions, utilizes the trainers trained

A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The expected impact will be the promotion of an effective and sustainable development 
using  external  resources,  which  is  aligned  with  Cambodia’s  Development  Cooperation  & 
Partnerships Strategy, 2014–2018.11 The expected outcome will be improved implementation of 
externally funded projects.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The TA outputs are the following: 
 
(i)  Mechanisms  for  project  preparation,  readiness,  and  implementation 
improved. This output will address systemic weaknesses in project preparation, 
start-up, and implementation. As new international practices have evolved, the 
government will review and update the contents of the SOPs for externally funded 
projects, taking into account the institutional and human capacity of the executing 
and implementing agencies. The project team will revisit project readiness filters 
and advance actions to accelerate project start-up time and take into account 
existing  government  regulations  for  the  detailed  step-by-step  implementing 
guidelines.  Government  chart  of  accounts  will  be  mainstreamed  in  project 
accounts of externally funded projects. The project team will acquire and configure 
needed  accounting  software  and  provide  training  for  the  executing  and 
implementing agencies. The project team will also review current institutional 
mechanisms for project implementation (e.g., project management unit structure, 
reporting lines, and roles and responsibilities of various government stakeholders 
involved  at  various  stages  of  the  project  cycle)  along  with  implementation 
processes and procedures, and provide recommendations for improvement.  
 
(ii)   Implementation  capacity  of  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies 
strengthened and sustained. This output will address long-term capacity needs 
of the government in managing externally funded projects. The project team will 
conduct a capacity needs assessment at the national and subnational levels and 
develop training programs to build the capacity of the executing and implementing 
agencies. The training programs will focus on procurement, financial management, 
monitoring  and  evaluation,  inclusive  development/gender  mainstreaming,  and 
other aspects relating to project management, incorporating the requirements of 
the SOPs and ADB financial management guidelines. The project team will further 
explore the possibility of partnering with national training institutions for long-term 
sustainability of capacity building efforts. About 400 executing and implementing 
agency staff at both the national and subnational levels will be trained. Through 
the TA, the project team will develop a training of trainers program to create a pool 
of 20 qualified trainers, link TA activities with the government and development 
partner programs, and institutionalize results with the national training institution.

effectiveness;  (c)  support  for  knowledge  partnerships  with  the  government, 
research institutes, development partners, and civil society organizations; and (d) 
conduct of periodical portfolio reviews in collaboration with the government and 
development partners. 
 
11.  The TA may encounter risks–lack of commitment to mainstream TA recommendations 
and difficulties in interagency coordination. To mitigate these risks, the project team will ensure 
thorough consultation with key stakeholders and disseminate its findings and recommendations 
widely. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,500,000, of which $1,400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of office space and travel of the counterpart staff. The 
cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The Ministry of Economy and Finance will be the executing agency. The ministry will (i) 
work closely with relevant line ministries to assess underlying issues regarding project readiness, 
preparation, and implementation; (ii) assess capacity building needs and develop the necessary 
training programs; (iii) work with a consulting firm, individual consultants and national training 
institutions  to  improve  project  implementation  and  portfolio  performance;  and  (iv)  ensure 
consistency  with  government  training  programs.  ADB’s  Cambodia  Resident  Mission  will 
administer the TA. The TA is scheduled to be implemented over 24 months, from 1 May 2017 to 
30 April 2019.  
 
14.  The TA project is estimated to require 25 person-months of international consultants and 
80 person-months of national consultant inputs. The TA will engage a consulting firm and 
individual consultants. ADB will recruit the international consulting firm using the quality- and cost-
based selection method with a standard quality–cost ratio of 90:10. Individual consultants will be 
selected through the individual consultant selection method.12 Consultant selection will be in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time).13 The TA will engage national training institutes through knowledge partnerships. The TA

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Overview 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will engage one consulting firm, individual consultants, and 
national training institutions. Upon mobilization of the individual consultants, an international 
consulting firm will be recruited using the quality- and cost-based selection method with a quality–
cost ratio of 90:10. It will be responsible for conducting a capacity needs assessment of executing 
and implementing agencies and developing a long-term capacity building program, which includes 
the appropriate methodology, estimation of the number of participants, and a timetable and work 
plan for the capacity building program. The consulting firm will work closely with individual 
consultants for their inputs and, later on, with the selected national training institutes that will 
deliver the training programs.  
 
2.  Individual consultants will be recruited early during the TA for quick implementation start-
up and provide on-the-job training in addition to their specialized tasks of reviewing the standard 
operating  procedures  (SOPs)  and  training  materials  in  their  specialized  areas  of expertise 
(particularly procurement, financial management, and gender mainstreaming) developed under 
previous TA projects. In addition, they will be on call to advise on resolving implementation issues 
in their areas of expertise. The assignments will be long term and selection will be based on the 
individual consultant selection method. Additional individual consultants who are knowledge 
management experts will be recruited halfway during the implementation of the TA to distill 
lessons learned, and assist the government in developing policies and strategies. 
 
3.  The TA will engage national training institutes in knowledge partnerships. The institutes 
will implement training programs developed by the consulting firm. Three or four training institutes 
will be selected to reduce the risk of nonperformance. A preliminary assessment of training 
institutes has been made with regard to staffing, facilities, and potential for long-term engagement. 
The final selection and arrangements will be confirmed during implementation.   
 
B.  Consulting Firm 
 
4.  Objectives and outputs. The overall objectives of the assignment are to conduct a 
capacity needs assessment and develop a long-term capacity building program to address the 
deficiencies in project preparation and implementation at the national and subnational levels.  
 
5.  Deliverables will include (i) an inception report, which outlines the scope, outputs, and 
completion schedule for  the  assignment; (ii)  a  mapping  and  inventory  of  capacity  building 
programs by the government and development partners, past and current trends, and capacity 
gaps; (iii) proposal for a medium- and long-term capacity building program for project preparation 
and implementation at the national and subnational levels with a horizon spanning 2018–2023, 
and (iv) a final report that integrates the main findings. The consulting firm will work closely with 
the specialized individual consultants to ensure quality and substantive inputs, as well as with the 
national training institutes that will implement the capacity building program.  
 
6.  Institutional development specialist and team leader (international, 3.5 person-
months).  The  specialist  will  have  a  master’s  degree  in  the  field  of  public  administration, 
economics, business management, or related fields with at least 5 years of experience in 
institutional development and is familiar with working in Cambodia and/or the Greater Mekong 
Subregion countries. The specialist will perform the following:

7.  Capacity building and training specialist (international, 2.0 person-months). The 
specialist will have at least a bachelor’s degree in the field of economics, education, public

capacity building and training programs, and is familiar with working in Cambodia and/or the 
Greater Mekong Subregion countries. The specialist will perform the following: 
 
(i)  review current training materials in the areas of project management, procurement, 
and financial management;  
(ii)  develop  training  approach,  methodology,  and  logistics,  along  with  evaluative 
measures to ensure the effectiveness of training materials and delivery;  
(iii)  develop and conduct a training program for project preparation and implementation 
for externally financed projects and coordinate the training program with individual 
consultants and selected national training institutes; 
(iv)  collaborate with the institutional development specialist to conduct stakeholders’ 
consultative workshops to obtain feedback on the capacity building program; 
(v)  assess the appropriateness of the overall training design and collaborate with 
national training institutes to develop appropriate training materials; and  
(vi)  evaluate the effectiveness of the training provided considering factors such as on-
the-job training and classroom training.  
 
8.  Institutional development specialist (national, 3.0 person-months). The specialist will 
have a bachelor’s degree in the field of public administration, business management, or related 
fields with at least 5 years of experience in project implementation and is familiar with working 
with international organizations. The specialist will have a good command of written and spoken 
English. The specialist will perform the following:

Appendix 3  11 
(i)  assist the international institutional development specialist in analyzing issues 
related to the administration of externally funded projects and prepare a capacity 
needs assessment; and 
(ii)  assist the team leader in collecting required data and preparing required reports. 
 
9.  Capacity building specialist (national, 3.0 person-months). The specialist will have a 
bachelor’s degree in the field of economics, education, public administration, or related fields with 
at  least  5  years  of  experience  in  project  implementation  and  is familiar  with  working  with 
international organizations. The specialist will have a good command of written and spoken 
English. The specialist will perform the following: 
 
(i)  assist the international capacity building and training specialist in preparing and 
reviewing the capacity needs assessment and capacity building programs as well 
as other aspects related to training, and 
(ii)  assist the capacity building and training specialist in collecting required data and 
preparing required reports.  
 
C.  Individual Consultants 
 
10.  Procurement specialist (international, 6.0 person-months).  The specialist will have a 
master’s degree in the field of engineering, applied economics, business management, or related 
fields with at least 5 years of experience in project implementation and is familiar with working in 
Cambodia and/or the Greater Mekong Subregion countries. The specialist will perform the 
following: 
 
(i)  review government reports and regulations on procurement (i.e., Procurement Law, 
SOPs and  Procurement  Manual,  and  various  subdecrees),  and  development 
partner reports and diagnostics; 
(ii)  review and update and revise the Procurement Manual based on and in alignment 
with current international practices; 
(iii)  review procurement processes and identify major bottlenecks in procurement; 
(iv)  review procurement training materials developed by previous Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) technical assistance and discuss with the selected consulting firm on 
proposed revisions to the materials; 
(v)  conduct an on-the-job training on procurement for staff of the executing and 
implementing  agencies  and  short-term  procurement  training  for  trainers  and 
trainees (three training sessions for 3 days for 20 trainees); 
(vi)  provide on-call and/or ad hoc support and advice to resolve project implementation 
issues with respect to procurement; and 
(vii)  prepare a report that summarizes the main findings and recommendations. 
 
11.  Financial management specialist (international, 5.0 person-months).  The specialist 
will have a master’s degree in the field of financial management or finance with at least 5 years 
of experience in project implementation and is familiar with working in Cambodia and/or the 
Greater Mekong Subregion countries. The specialist is required to have knowledge of ADB and 
government requirements on financial management. The specialist will perform the following: 
 
(i)  review government regulations and development partner reports and diagnostics 
on financial management; 
(ii)  review and update and revise the Financial Management Manual based on current 
international practices;

12  Appendix 3 
 
(iii)  review financial management and disbursement processes and identify major 
bottlenecks in financial management;  
(iv)  review  existing  financial  management  and  accounting  software  and  propose 
recommendations on the use of software (including the possibility of acquiring new 
software); 
(v)  assist the Ministry of Economy and Finance in mainstreaming the government 
chart of accounts in the development partners’ project accounts; 
(vi)  review  financial  management  training  materials  developed  by  previous  ADB 
technical assistance and discuss with the selected consulting firm on proposed 
revisions to the materials;  
(vii)  conduct on-the-job training for staff of the executing and implementing agencies 
and short-term financial management training for trainers and trainees (three 
training sessions for 3 days for 20 trainees);  
(viii)  provide on-call and/or ad hoc support and advice to resolve project implementation 
issues with respect to financial management and disbursement; and 
(ix)  prepare a report that summarizes the main findings and recommendations. 
 
12.  Gender  specialist  (international,  2.5  person-months).  The  specialist  will  have  a 
master’s degree in sociology, gender, or related fields with at least 5 years of experience in project 
implementation and is familiar with working in Cambodia and/or the Greater Mekong Subregion 
countries. The specialist will perform the following: 
 
(i)  review  training  materials  on  gender  mainstreaming  in  project  preparation  and 
implementation, and 
(ii)  design and prepare training materials for a modular gender training program. 
 
13.  Knowledge management specialists (international, 6.0 person-months total, on-
demand basis). The specialists will have a master’s degree in the field of economics or related 
fields with at least 5 years of experience and are familiar with working in Cambodia and/or the 
Greater Mekong Subregion countries. The specialists will perform the following 
 
(i)  conduct  discussions  and  consultations  with  key  government  ministries  and 
agencies, development partners, research institutions, and other stakeholders to 
gain an in-depth understanding of national, sector, and thematic development 
issues and priorities; 
(ii)  support knowledge production in areas the government wishes to address to 
achieve economic and social development effectiveness at the strategic, national, 
and sector level;  
(iii)  prepare briefing materials, discussion notes, and keynote presentations on the 
effectiveness of project management and government development priorities; and    
(iv)  support strategic knowledge partnerships with academic institutions, think tanks, 
the government, development partners, and civil society institutions through joint 
knowledge production, dissemination, and events. 
 
D.   National Training Institutes 
 
14.  The selected national training institutes will implement the capacity building program and 
carry out the actual training of various aspects of project management (financial management, 
procurement, and project management). The training institutes will discuss with the Ministry of 
Economy and Finance and ADB the relevance and appropriateness of the materials developed 
earlier by the consulting firm and specialized individual consultants. The national training institutes

Appendix 3  13 
will have extensive experience in conducting training programs for government officials in the field 
of  public  administration,  project  management,  or  related  fields.  The  scope  of  work  and 
deliverables include the following:  
 
(i)  review  appropriate  training  materials  in  financial  management,  procurement, 
project management, and related fields; 
(ii)  prepare  a  training  implementation  program  for  400  participants,  along  with 
evaluation indicators and feedback forms;  
(iii)  monitor progress and conduct tests and other evaluative mechanisms to provide 
feedback on training effectiveness; and  
(iv)  conduct workshops and training activities. 
 
15.  The national training institutes will each require the services of one part-time advisor and 
one full-time administrative coordinator (20 person-months). Overall, a total of 54 person-months 
of trainers will be required. Detailed terms of reference will be provided during implementation.
